answer.text: First, please visit the 'IDEAS' section to access the instructions. Once you have done that, kindly return here to practice.
To practice and improve, please use the following model answer as an example:

Who should pay for the preservation of historic buildings?
The preservation of historic buildings is an important aspect of maintaining our cultural heritage, and I think that it's a shared responsibility between government and private individuals. Governments have an obligation to protect cultural landmarks and monuments, and they should provide funding to support preservation efforts. At the same time, private individuals and organizations can contribute to the preservation of these structures by donating money, resources, or by volunteering their time. In some cases, the owners of historic buildings may be responsible for maintaining them. If a building has been designated as a protected cultural site, the owner may be required to preserve the building to a certain standard, and may be eligible for financial assistance from the government to help with the cost of preservation. However, the preservation of historic buildings can be an expensive and complex process, and often requires collaboration between multiple stakeholders. The public and private sectors must work together to ensure that historic buildings are protected, preserved, and maintained for future generations to enjoy. To sum up, the preservation of historic buildings requires a multi-faceted approach, with a combination of government funding, private contributions, and community involvement. It is important to ensure that these structures are protected and preserved so that they can continue to serve as a cultural heritage for future generations.

What's the difference between payment for mental work and that for physical work?
These days, mental work is usually paid more than physical work for several reasons. First, people who do mental work, like office jobs, often need special education or skills, which makes their salaries higher. On the other hand, physical work, like construction, doesn’t always require formal education, so it’s paid less. Second, mental work is often connected to jobs in technology or business, and these fields are in high demand. Because of this, they pay more. Physical jobs, however, are not as popular, so the salaries are usually lower. Finally, some physical jobs can now be done by machines, which means people in those jobs are paid less. But mental work, like creating or managing technology, can’t be replaced easily, so it’s seen as more valuable and pays more.

Can physical workers receive higher salaries in the future?
Sure. There’s a pretty good chance their salaries will go up, if their work remains essential (I mean, if they’re not replaced by robots or automation), and at the same time if there’s a shortage of workers. This could be the case since nowadays, people are more interested in AI and IT, and fewer want to do physical work. If fewer people want to do physical jobs because they prefer office work or technology, companies might pay more to attract workers. Plus, as technology improves, some physical jobs might need workers to know how to use new machines or tools. For example, a worker in a factory might need to learn how to use special robots. This extra knowledge makes the job more important, so the workers might get paid more.

What kinds of jobs need a lot of physical work?
There are a lot of jobs that require physical work. For example, nurses have very demanding jobs. They often need to help patients move, which means they have to lift or support them. They also spend most of their day walking or standing, and they carry medical equipment, which can be quite heavy. Another job that requires a lot of physical work is construction. Construction workers have to carry heavy materials like bricks and wood, use big tools, and sometimes climb up high buildings. They also work outside in all kinds of weather, which makes their job even harder. Finally, farmers also do a lot of physical labor. They spend long hours planting, watering, and harvesting crops. If they take care of animals, they have to carry heavy food and water for them. Farmers often work under the sun or in cold weather, which can be very tiring.

Do you think that nowadays all jobs could be done by robots?
Well, on the one hand, ‘yes' as over the last few years robots and computers have made tremendous leaps in the performance and capabilities. But on the other hand, I think it concerns only repetitive or monotonous jobs as well as mechanical jobs that involve mass production, as they are carried out in precisely controlled conditions and are therefore amenable to the use of robots. Though I can't imagine robots instead of humans in the jobs that require creative thinking, problem-solving skills, leadership, teamwork and initiative, and I believe that we, humans, will still thrive in the workforce thanks to our social intelligence and empathy, as well as higher-order skills and cognition. What are the benefits of replacing human workers with robots?
Well, to my mind, the primary benefits of robotization are speed and safety. Unlike human staff, robots don't get distracted or need to take breaks. They also never feel stressed out, and can work all the time, which speeds up production. As far as safety is concerned, robots are a great solution for employers whose human workers have to work at hot temperature or with sharp objects, as machines can easily do tasks of any risk and difficulty level. I'd also add to my list such benefits as consistency as robots never need to divide their attention between a multitude of things and always do just what they are supposed to do……. accuracy as robots are programmed for precise, repetitive motion and they are less likely to make mistakes, which means they will always perform tasks with more accuracy than humans…… and cost as robots are definitely much cheaper than humans.

What are the differences between difficult jobs and easy jobs?
I think the main difference is that difficult jobs are often more physically demanding. For example, construction work or being a chef can require long hours of standing, lifting, or running around. On the other hand, easy jobs might be less tiring, like sitting at a desk and working on a computer. Secondly, some tough jobs can be mentally draining, like being a doctor or a lawyer, where you have to make important decisions under pressure. Easy jobs might be less stressful, like working in a store or something that doesn’t require a lot of problem-solving. Another difference is that hard jobs usually need more specific skills or experience. For example, becoming an engineer or a teacher takes a lot of training. Easy jobs might just need basic skills or even no experience, like working in fast food or as a cashier. Finally, tough jobs can sometimes mean crazy hours. Like in healthcare, you might have to work nights or weekends. Easier jobs tend to have more regular hours, like a 9-to-5 job. As for job satisfaction, difficult jobs can feel more rewarding because you know you’re making a bigger impact, like helping people or solving big problems. But easier jobs can still be satisfying if they let you have more free time or are more relaxed.

answer.text:
What qualities do people need to do difficult jobs?
First of all, they need to be patient, because tough jobs take time, and things don't always go as planned. Like, doctors need patience when dealing with difficult patients, and teachers need it when students don’t get something right away. They also need to be resourceful, because problems always pop up. For example, a mechanic might run into a bigger issue while fixing a car and needs to figure out the best way to deal with it. Resilience is important too. They have to be strong, both physically and mentally. Firefighters, for example, carry heavy gear and work in really tough conditions, so they need to be tough. Being level-headed is huge. They can’t lose their cool when things get stressful. Like, a firefighter has to stay calm and give clear directions in dangerous situations. They also need to be adaptable because things don’t always go according to plan. For example, a chef in a busy kitchen has to quickly adjust when the place gets crowded or when they add a new dish to the menu. And finally, they need to be responsible. If they're not, it can cause serious problems. Like, a construction worker needs to be careful with safety, or accidents can happen.

answer.text:
What role can robots play in the car manufacturing process?
Robots play a huge role in car manufacturing because they handle tasks in areas that are too hot, cold, or noisy for humans. For example, some factories store materials in freezing conditions, like certain car battery components, but robots can work there just fine without any special gear. In areas where metal parts are welded or molded, the heat would be unbearable for humans, but robots can operate without any issues. They also help make molded plastic parts like bumpers and interior panels, as well as injection-molded components and molded rubber seals used throughout the car. Robots are used for these tasks because they’re super precise and can keep production fast and consistent without mistakes or slowdowns. Loud machinery, like stamping presses that shape metal parts, can be harmful to human hearing, but robots can work there safely. Painting cars also involves hazardous chemicals and fumes, so robots do the job in sealed environments to protect workers. Finally, robots move and assemble large, heavy parts like car frames and engines, reducing the risk of injuries from lifting accidents.

Should scientists explain the research process to the public?
I think it would be good if they did so. First of all, transparency would play a significant role in demystifying scientific practices, dispelling misconceptions, and building a stronger relationship between scientists and the public. For example, when climate scientists explain their methodologies for collecting data and running simulations, it helps the public understand the severity of climate change and the urgency of action. In addition, sharing the research process can inspire the younger generation to pursue careers in science and research. Finally, public dissemination of the research process helps in dispelling skepticism surrounding scientific findings. For example, when vaccine researchers explain the rigorous testing procedures and safety evaluations, it can address concerns and build confidence in the efficacy and safety of vaccines.

Why do some children not like learning science at school?
Some children may not enjoy learning science at school due to various reasons. Firstly, they might have a hard time relating scientific concepts to their daily lives, making it seem abstract and uninteresting. What science subject is the most important for children to learn?
I believe that Biology is a fundamental science subject that children should prioritize in their education. Firstly, Biology helps youngsters understand the complexities of life itself, including human anatomy, ecosystems, and the diversity of species on Earth. This knowledge is not only fascinating but also essential for making informed decisions about health and environmental conservation. Furthermore, by studying Biology, children can develop critical thinking skills as they learn about biological processes and the impact of factors like pollution and climate change on living organisms. Moreover, Biology has numerous real-world applications. For instance, it's the foundation for medical and healthcare professions, which play a vital role in society. Additionally, Biology underpins advancements in biotechnology, such as genetic engineering and pharmaceutical research. Therefore, a strong foundation in Biology equips children with valuable skills and knowledge that can lead to rewarding careers and contribute to solving global challenges like disease outbreaks and environmental sustainability.

What science subject is the most important for children to learn?
In my view, Computer Science is an incredibly important science subject for children in today's digital age. To begin with, computers are ubiquitous in our lives, from smartphones to laptops, and understanding the principles of Computer Science is essential for navigating this technology-driven world. Learning Computer Science empowers children to not only use these devices effectively but also to create software and solve complex problems. Furthermore, Computer Science fosters critical thinking and problem-solving skills. It teaches children how to break down problems into smaller steps and develop algorithms, which are valuable skills not only in programming but also in many other areas of life. Moreover, Computer Science is a gateway to exciting career opportunities in fields like software development, data science, and artificial intelligence. Additionally, Computer Science plays a pivotal role in innovation and technological advancements. It's the foundation of industries driving economic growth and global connectivity. Therefore, by emphasizing Computer Science in education, we are preparing the next generation to be competitive in the job market and to contribute to the ongoing digital transformation of society.

Absolutely. A national identity is what unites all citizens into one nation. It builds a strong bond among all members of the society. So, first of all, it plays a key role in creating and maintaining a democracy and political order in society. What's more, a national identity is the basis of national security. I mean when people feel they belong in a particular society, they feel as a part of this group, they are less likely to break the law or hurt others in any way. Another reason why a national identity matters is that a common identity defines citizens' membership in a country and places them in relation to other persons who are also citizens, or other persons from other countries. Also, a national identity plays a key role in determining whether people view immigration as a threat - those who identify with their country are more negative toward immigration. What are the differences in television viewing habits between the elderly and the young?
Well, there are quite a few differences, actually. For one, the type of content is different. The elderly often prefer news, talk shows, documentaries, or classic movies, while young people are more into series, reality shows, YouTube content, and entertainment. Another big difference is the platform: older people usually watch TV on a traditional television set, but young people tend to use smartphones, tablets, or laptops, and they go for streaming services like Netflix, YouTube, or TikTok. The viewing time is also different. Older people might watch TV more regularly and at fixed times, like after lunch or in the evening, while younger people watch whenever they want since they prefer on-demand content. Their viewing habits are different too: the elderly might watch TV passively, kind of like background activity, but younger viewers often binge-watch shows or go for short clips with high engagement. And the purpose of watching is not the same. Older people might use TV for company, background noise, or just to feel connected to the world, while young people usually watch it for fun, distraction, or relaxation. Also, older people might watch with their spouse or family, but young people often watch alone or talk about shows online with friends.

What are the differences between sitting next to someone who talks on the phone and sitting next to people who talk to each other while travelling by train?
From my experience, phone conversations are way more distracting. People usually speak louder when they’re on the phone, probably without even realising it. Plus, you only hear one side of the conversation, and for some reason, that makes it harder to ignore. Your brain keeps guessing what the other person’s saying. When two people are chatting face to face, it sounds more natural and less annoying. They also tend to be more aware of their surroundings and speak more quietly. Phone calls can sometimes get awkward too, like when someone starts talking about personal stuff in public. I’ve definitely had moments when I wished I could move to another seat. But of course, it depends. Some people are really considerate, no matter who they’re talking to.

Yes, I think parents should teach their children to behave well in public because it helps kids learn respect for others. When children know how to act in public, they learn to be polite and not disturb other people. It also makes public spaces more pleasant for everyone. Nobody enjoys being around screaming kids or mess. Plus, it prepares them for real life. One day they’ll need to work, travel, or study with others, so learning basic manners early is important. Another thing is, bad behaviour reflects on the parents. Let’s be honest, when a child is acting out in public, most people blame the parents. So yeah, I think it’s just part of raising responsible people.

Should parents teach their children to behave well in public?
No, I don’t think parents should teach their children to behave well in public because children are still learning. They’re not robots. It’s normal for kids to be noisy or curious. Some people behave as if children don’t belong in public places, but kids have every right to be there just like anyone else. Also, too much control can harm a child’s confidence. If you constantly tell kids to be quiet or sit still, they might become anxious or afraid to express themselves. And in the end, cultural expectations vary. What’s seen as bad behaviour in one place might be totally fine in another.

What’s the difference between food in your country and Western food?
Well, Filipino food is really different from Western food in terms of flavor. We love mixing sweet, salty, and sour tastes in one dish. For example, adobo is cooked with vinegar and soy sauce, which gives it a strong and tangy flavor. In Western food, I think the flavors are more straightforward and not as mixed. Also, we don’t really use much dairy. Cheese, cream, or butter aren’t very common in our cooking. Rice is our main staple, while in many Western countries it’s more about bread or potatoes. Portions are different too. Filipino meals are usually shared family-style, while Western meals are more individual. Overall, our food is bold and full of character.

What’s the difference between food in your country and Western food?
Uzbek food is quite hearty and filling, which is different from typical Western meals. We eat a lot of plov. It’s a rice dish with lamb, carrots, and spices, and it’s really flavorful. Our food tends to be meat-heavy, especially with lamb and beef. Bread is also a big part of every meal. It’s almost sacred in our culture. Western food seems a bit lighter and uses more sauces or dressings. We use fewer dairy products and don’t really focus on things like cheese or cream. Also, we cook in big portions, and everyone eats from the same dishes. The flavors in Uzbek food are more earthy and rich.

What’s the difference between food in your country and Western food?
Food in Arab countries is very flavorful and based on spices like cumin, cinnamon, and turmeric. We eat a lot of grilled meats, rice, and dishes made from chickpeas, like hummus and falafel. Bread is more common than rice in some regions, especially flatbread. Compared to Western food, our meals are more centered around shared dishes and family-style eating. Western food often has more variety in vegetables and dairy products. Our dishes are heavier on spices but not always spicy, just rich in taste. Also, sweets in Arab countries tend to use honey and nuts rather than chocolate or cream. There’s a strong sense of hospitality around meals too.

What’s the difference between food in your country and Western food?
Chinese food is super diverse, but in general, it’s more focused on balance, like balancing sweet, salty, and umami flavors. We use a lot of soy sauce, ginger, garlic, and sesame oil in cooking. Compared to Western food, our meals usually have more vegetables, and meat is more of a side than the main focus. Also, we eat rice or noodles every day, while in the West it’s more about bread, pasta, or potatoes. Chinese dishes are often cooked quickly, like in stir-fries, while Western meals are sometimes baked or roasted. We don’t use much cheese or butter, and desserts are usually lighter. The variety is huge. Each region has its own style.

What’s the difference between food in your country and Western food?
Indian food is known for its bold and spicy flavors, which makes it quite different from Western cuisine. We use a lot of spices, not just for heat, but for aroma and taste, like turmeric, cumin, and garam masala. Many dishes are vegetarian, and lentils are a big part of everyday meals. In contrast, Western food usually includes more meat and is milder in flavor. Also, Indian meals are often served with rice or flatbreads like naan, instead of bread or potatoes. We don’t eat much raw salad. Most things are cooked or spiced. Our food can be oily or creamy, especially in curries, and everything is made fresh. Eating with hands is also common in many regions.

What’s the difference between food in your country and Western food?
Ukrainian food is very hearty and filling. We love soups like borsch, dumplings, and dishes made with potatoes and cabbage. It’s quite different from Western food, which often feels lighter and more focused on salads or quick meals. We often eat pickled vegetables, especially in winter, which you don’t see much in the West. Bread is always on the table, and meat, usually pork or chicken, is a big part of most meals. Our food isn’t very spicy, but it’s got a sour taste because we use a lot of fermented ingredients. Western cuisine also uses more dairy like cheese and cream sauces, while we mostly stick to sour cream. Our food is all about comfort and tradition.

What’s the difference between food in your country and Western food?
Azerbaijani food is full of herbs, spices, and rich flavors. We use a lot of lamb and rice, and dishes like dolma and kebab are very common. Our cuisine is influenced by the Middle East and Central Asia, so it’s very aromatic. In Western food, I think the spices are more subtle, and the meals are simpler. For example, in a Western meal you might have meat, potatoes, and a salad, while our dishes are more layered and cooked slowly. We also eat lots of greens and yogurt-based sauces. I’d say our food is more about depth of flavor than presentation. It feels more traditional and homey.

Are people influenced by famous people?
Not everyone is influenced by famous people, and not in every way. Some people think that if they do the same things as celebrities, they’ll become as rich, famous, or successful. For example, they might wear the same clothes, use the same brands, or follow the same trends. They believe that copying a celebrity’s lifestyle will bring them the same kind of success. But then there are others who are more confident and have their own opinions about things. They know who they are and make their own decisions based on what they believe, not on what they see others doing, including famous people. It also depends on the kind of behavior celebrities show. Some people only copy the good things celebrities do. For instance, if a celebrity supports a charity or works hard, others might follow their example. But when celebrities act badly, like using harmful substances or getting into trouble, there are people who won’t copy that because they follow their own moral compass. They don’t want to imitate behavior they think is wrong. Unfortunately, there are people who think that copying everything a celebrity does, even their bad habits, will make them successful too. They believe that if they live their lives the way celebrities do, they’ll become just as popular or successful. So, for those people, famous people influence almost every area of their life.

It really depends on the person’s age, their relationships, and their situation. When you’re young, you rely more on your parents for everything, so they influence you the most. They don't pay attention to the fact that by wasting water they are depriving others of a basic necessity for survival. What are the characteristics of goods transported by water?
First of all, water transport is often preferred for bulk commodities such as grains, coal, ore, and petroleum products due to the cost-effectiveness of transporting large volumes at once. Secondly, water transport plays a crucial role in containerized trade, with goods packed in standardized shipping containers because containers allow for efficient handling, stacking, and secure transportation of various goods. Containerized goods are diverse and include consumer products, machinery, electronics, clothing, and more. Another type of goods often transported by water is perishable goods like fresh produce, seafood, and flowers as water transport allows for extended shelf life compared to other modes of transportation. There are those specialized refrigerated or 'reefer' vessels that maintain controlled temperature and humidity conditions to preserve the quality and freshness of these goods. Water transport is also preferred for transporting heavy and oversized cargo that may not be feasible for other modes of transportation. This includes large machinery, vehicles, construction equipment, and components of infrastructure projects. Finally, water transport is involved in the shipment of hazardous materials, including chemicals, gases, and oils because ships designed for hazardous cargo are equipped with specialized containment systems and safety protocols to prevent leaks, spills, and accidents during transportation.

Similarly, lakes and rivers can influence local temperatures, which makes the surrounding areas more pleasant to live in.

What are the benefits and drawbacks of consumerism for a country's economy?
Well, as far as the pros of consumerism are concerned, it stimulates economic growth by creating a never-ending cycle of buying and selling. The more goods are consumed by society, the higher the growth rate of the economy is. But unfortunately, this economic growth is possible only if all these consumer goods are not only consumed but also produced within the country. In real life, consumerism has more cons, to my mind, as the more it spreads, the weaker is the incentive to manufacture long-lasting, quality products, and the greater is the likelihood that cheaply made products will instead be imported from the lowest-wage, environmentally unregulated overseas manufacturers. This usually leads to the loss of manufacturing jobs, which in turn leads to a corresponding growth in unemployment and the number of welfare recipients, less personal wealth, a shrinking tax base, fewer public services and greater public and private debt, hopelessness for job seekers and a growing negative balance of trade.

During the pandemic, some farmers saw an increase in their income. This was especially true for those who provided essential food products like vegetables, fruits, and dairy. Local farmers who sold directly to customers or to supermarkets benefited from this surge in demand. Plus, many people turned to online shopping, which helped small-scale farmers reach more customers and sell their products. On the flip side, some farmers saw their income drop during the pandemic. This mainly affected those who supplied restaurants, hotels, and businesses connected to tourism. When those businesses shut down, people just weren’t buying things like fancy foods or specialty products anymore. Farmers who relied on large-scale distribution or exports also struggled. However, excessive noise can be disruptive in certain settings, and it's important to be mindful of others' needs for a peaceful and quiet environment. For example, in public spaces like parks or playgrounds, children's noise levels are expected and acceptable, as these areas are designated for play and fun. But in places like restaurants, libraries, or hospitals, excessive noise can be disturbing and disruptive to other patrons or patients trying to enjoy their meals or rest. Moreover, in schools or classrooms, children should be taught to keep their noise levels to a minimum to ensure a productive learning environment and respect for the learning process of other children. Teachers may use noise as part of their teaching strategies, but it should be balanced with the need for a quiet and peaceful classroom. In addition, it's important to consider the impact of noise on the environment and wildlife. Loud noise can have negative effects on the environment and children should be taught to be mindful of the impact their noise levels have on it. In conclusion, children should be allowed to express themselves and have fun, but it's crucial to find a balance between self-expression and respect for others' needs for a peaceful and quiet environment. Parents, caregivers, and children should be aware of the noise levels they produce and adjust accordingly in different settings to respect others.

What are the differences between cheap and expensive clothes?
When you compare cheap and expensive clothes, there are a few things that usually stand out. First, the quality of the materials is a big factor. Expensive clothes often use nicer fabrics that feel better on the skin, last longer, and keep their shape and color after washing. Cheap clothes, on the other hand, tend to use synthetic or lower-quality materials that might wear out quickly or lose their look after a few washes. Another difference is how the clothes are made. High-end brands usually pay more attention to the details like stronger stitching, reinforced seams, and buttons that stay on. With cheaper clothes, you might notice loose threads or uneven seams, and sometimes buttons can fall off easily. There’s also the brand and status side of things. Expensive brands are often well-known and carry a kind of prestige or luxury vibe, while cheaper clothes usually come from less famous brands and don’t have that same image. But if you think about value for money, sometimes the more expensive clothes can actually be a better deal in the long run. Because they last longer and keep looking good, you don’t have to replace them as often. Cheap clothes might be affordable at first, but you end up buying new ones more frequently. Finally, expensive clothes are often more exclusive or limited edition, which can make them feel special. Cheap clothes tend to be mass-produced and easy to find everywhere.

Which age group is the best at learning new things?
I believe children, especially those between 5 and 12 years old, are the best at learning new things. At that age, their brains are more flexible, which means they can absorb information much faster than adults. They pick up new languages, skills, and habits almost effortlessly. Also, they’re naturally curious and open-minded, so they enjoy exploring new topics. Of course, they might not understand complex ideas like adults, but when it comes to learning through play or experience, they’re really quick. Adults often overthink or hesitate, but kids just try without fear. So, for me, children are the most effective learners, especially in areas like languages or creative tasks. Their ability to learn is truly impressive.

Which age group is the best at learning new things?
In my opinion, young adults, around 20 to 35 years old, are the best at learning new things. They usually have clear goals, whether it’s career development or personal growth, so they’re more focused and motivated. Unlike children, they can manage their time better and have access to online courses, mentors, and other learning tools. They may not learn as fast as kids, but their understanding is often deeper. Also, they can think critically and apply knowledge in real-life situations. I think motivation plays a big role too. If someone wants to learn, they’ll find a way, no matter their age. Still, young adults have a great balance of brain flexibility and life experience. That’s why I think they learn most effectively.

Which age group is the best at learning new things?
I think the best age group for learning new things really depends on what kind of learning we’re talking about. For example, young children have very flexible brains, so they can learn languages or physical skills quickly. However, teenagers and young adults tend to be better at understanding complex ideas because they can think more critically. Older adults might learn slower, but their life experience helps them connect new knowledge to real situations. Also, motivation plays a big role at any age. Someone who wants to learn will find a way. So, while kids are great at absorbing information fast, adults often have better focus and discipline. Overall, each age group has its own strengths when it comes to learning.

It’s the kind of view that makes you want to stop and just take it all in.

It's really hard to say whether there are more beautiful things now than in the past as beauty is a matter of personal preference. What one person finds beautiful may not be the same as what another person finds beautiful. Some people may argue that there are more beautiful things now because of technological advancements and the ability to create and appreciate art in different ways. What effect will it have on students if a teacher is impatient with them?
Honestly, I think if a teacher is impatient, it can really hurt the learning process. The thing is, language learning takes time. An impatient person usually struggles when things don’t happen quickly. They get annoyed if someone needs more time to understand something or makes the same mistake again. So if a teacher acts like that and shows frustration when students take too long to answer or repeat themselves, it creates pressure. As a result, some students just shut down. They stop talking and stop trying because they might feel like they’re annoying the teacher or holding up the class. Instead of building confidence, the classroom starts to feel stressful. And when that happens again and again, students can actually start to dislike the subject altogether. They might even start believing they’re just bad at languages, which usually isn’t true at all. It’s just that they didn’t feel supported.

What are some good ways to persuade children?
Well, from what I’ve seen, positive reinforcement works really well. My little cousin, for example, never wanted to clean up his toys… until his parents started praising him every time he did it. Now he even reminds them to say ‘Well done’! Another trick that helps is giving children choices. When I babysit, I never say ‘Go brush your teeth.’ I ask, ‘Do you want to brush your teeth now or after your bedtime story?’ It sounds simple, but they feel more in control and don’t argue. Also, I’ve noticed that if you explain the reason why you need something done, it makes a huge difference. Kids aren’t robots. If they understand why, they usually cooperate. And of course, staying calm and patient is key. If you start raising your voice, they just stop listening completely.

How does advertising influence children and their parents?
Well, children are an extremely vulnerable target audience because they are cognitively and psychologically defenseless against advertising. Children take everything they see at face value, and therefore they are easy to persuade. So if the ad says that it is a Snickers that satisfies hunger best, they are likely to opt for a Snickers rather than healthy snacks. They quickly get used to consuming unhealthy food, and then they become adults who lead an unhealthy lifestyle. Also, children are not able to understand the persuasive character of advertising messages. However, they absorb these messages like a sponge. This may cause changes in children's behaviour. For example, some children make excessive demands on their parents for the products they see in ads, especially if these products were advertised by their favourite cartoon or film characters. And some kids even have temper tantrums in public if their parents refuse to buy this or that thing.

When two people have an argument, do you think they should find a third party to ask for advice?
Honestly, I don’t think it’s always necessary. A lot of the time, it’s better to just talk things through directly, especially if it’s something personal. If you bring someone else in too early, it can feel like you’re making a big deal out of something small, or like you're trying to get backup. And sometimes the third person doesn’t even know the full story, so their advice might not actually help. But there are moments when having someone neutral really makes a difference. Like, if the same argument keeps coming up over and over and you’re just going in circles. That’s when an outside opinion might help you see what you’re missing. Or if things get really emotional and you’re both too upset to listen properly, a third person can kind of slow things down and help you focus on what really matters. Also, sometimes it’s just easier to open up when there’s someone else there, especially if that person is someone both sides trust. They can keep things calm and make sure everyone actually gets heard. So yeah, I don’t think every little disagreement needs outside help, but in tougher situations, it can really help move things forward and stop things from getting worse.

Which is more important, a work-related appointment or an appointment with a friend? Why?
I’d say in most cases, a work-related appointment is more important. First of all, it affects your reputation. If you show up late or cancel last minute, people might see you as unreliable, and that can stick for a long time. Especially if it's with a client or a manager, it’s not just about being polite… it’s about your whole image. And also, other people may rely on you, especially in team projects or meetings. Your absence can slow things down or even mess up deadlines. Friendships are super important too, of course, but work stuff tends to have more immediate consequences. You can usually explain things to a friend and reschedule without much harm. But in work settings, people expect you to be professional no matter what.

Which is more important, a work-related appointment or an appointment with a friend? Why?
Honestly, for me, an appointment with a friend can be more important, depending on the situation. I mean, friends support your mental health. If you’re always cancelling on people just because of work, it starts to affect how connected you feel. Having someone to talk to, laugh with, or just share your day is not something to treat like a backup plan. Also, it shows you value the relationship when you make time for them. We all get busy, but showing up for someone when you said you would… that matters. Work will always be there, but people won’t wait forever. And sometimes, that one coffee with a friend can make a way bigger difference in your week than another meeting.

If someone doesn’t really like whom they are going to meet, they may deliberately miss their appointment. Is that true? Why?
Yeah, I think it’s definitely true for some people. Like, it’s easier to cancel than to confront, right? If you don’t enjoy someone’s company, the idea of sitting through a meeting or lunch with them can be super uncomfortable. So instead of saying, “Hey, I don’t want to meet,” they just skip it or cancel last minute. It’s not the most mature way, but it happens. Also, they don’t want to waste time on people they dislike. Time is limited, and not everyone wants to spend it with someone who drains their energy. So yeah, I’ve seen people do this, and honestly, I kind of get it. It’s not great, but it’s human.

If someone doesn’t really like whom they are going to meet, they may deliberately miss their appointment. Is that true? Why?
I’m not sure that’s always true. I mean, some people just feel obligated to show up anyway, even if they’re not excited about the meeting. Maybe they were raised to be polite, or maybe they just don’t want drama. Also, it’s possible to be professional without liking someone. In work or social settings, you can be civil and get through it without turning it into a big emotional thing. People cancel for lots of reasons, and not all of them have to do with feelings. I think most adults try to follow through on plans, even if it’s not their favorite person. It’s just part of life. You deal with people you don’t click with.

How do people who are busy remember things they need to do?
I think most busy people survive thanks to writing to-do lists. It sounds basic, but it really works… just dumping everything out of your head onto paper or into your phone helps a lot. Personally, I do this every night before bed so I don’t lie awake thinking about things. I also rely on calendar apps. They send me notifications at the exact time I need to do something, which is super helpful when I’ve got a packed day. Without these two things, I’d probably forget half my responsibilities. And it’s not even about memory. It’s more about clearing mental space. When you know it’s written somewhere, your brain relaxes a little. So yeah, I think it’s all about systems, not superhuman memory.

How do people who are busy remember things they need to do?
Honestly, when people are super busy, they just need quick and easy ways to stay on top of things. One thing that works surprisingly well is putting sticky notes around their space. I’ve seen friends stick them on the fridge, the bathroom mirror, even their laptop. It looks a bit old-school, but it totally does the job. It’s like having little pop-up reminders all over your place. And then there’s following a strict daily routine... that helps a lot too. When your day has a rhythm, you don’t have to think so hard about what comes next. Like, you just know… emails in the morning, meetings after lunch, errands in the evening. It takes a lot of pressure off your brain. So yeah, even though it’s all pretty simple, it really works.

Do you think the style of the clothing is more important than its comfort?
To me, comfort definitely comes first. Like, I don’t want to spend the whole day adjusting my clothes or feeling too hot or squeezed into something tight just because it looks cool. If I’m not comfortable, I’m probably not enjoying myself. At the same time, I like to wear things that look good, but only if they’re comfortable. I think these days, it’s actually pretty easy to find clothes that are both stylish and comfortable. So I don’t feel like I have to choose. But if I had to pick one, I’d go with comfort. Because honestly, even the most fashionable outfit won’t save your mood if you can’t breathe or sit properly in it.

Do you think the style of the clothing is more important than its comfort?
I guess it depends on the situation. If I’m just staying home, then yeah, comfort is all that matters. But when I’m out, style usually comes first. I mean, I don’t want to feel totally uncomfortable, but I’d rather wear something that looks really good, even if it’s not the most comfortable thing ever. If I’m going out or meeting people, I want to feel confident, and for me, that comes from wearing something stylish. Sometimes I put up with slightly tight jeans or shoes that aren’t super comfy just because the outfit looks great.

What factors affect people’s decisions when buying clothes?
There are quite a few things people think about when they buy clothes. First of all, there’s the price. If something is too expensive, many people won’t even bother trying it on. But if it’s affordable and looks decent, it’s more tempting. Comfort and fit are big factors too. An item might look great on a hanger or in a photo, but if it doesn’t feel good or fit right, most people will pass. The reason for buying also plays a role. If it’s for a special occasion, like a wedding or a job interview, people usually put more thought into it. But if it’s just for everyday wear, like grabbing a hoodie, they’re more relaxed about the choice. Trends matter too. People who care about style often choose what’s fashionable at the moment rather than going for classic pieces. Many also stick to brands they already trust, because it’s easier when they know the size and quality. And finally, more people are paying attention to things like sustainability and where their clothes are made. So overall, it’s a mix of price, comfort, purpose, personal style, and sometimes values.

answer.text:
Do you think it’s a good idea to buy clothes online?
To be honest, I don’t really like buying clothes online. The biggest issue for me is that you can’t try anything on. Like, something might look great on the model or even seem like the right size on paper, but when it arrives, it just fits weird. Maybe it’s too tight in one spot or way too long. And you can't really tell what the fabric feels like or how it actually looks on you. And okay, even if the website has an easy return policy, it’s still a whole process. You’ve got to pack it up again, print the label, drop it off somewhere, and then wait for your money to come back. It just takes time and effort, especially if you’re busy. Plus, I feel like you never really know what you’re going to get. Sometimes the color is off, or the material feels super cheap compared to the pictures. So yeah, I’d rather go to a store, try things on, and be sure about what I’m getting right away. It just saves me a lot of hassle.

Do you think it’s a good idea to buy clothes online?
Honestly, I think buying clothes online can be really convenient, especially if you’re not super picky about how things fit. Like, for basic stuff (T-shirts, hoodies, even oversized things) it doesn’t really matter if it’s a little loose or not perfect. You just need something comfortable, and boom, it shows up at your door. It also saves a ton of time. You don’t have to go anywhere, wait in line, or try stuff on under those horrible fitting room lights. You just scroll, click, and you’re done. And if you already know your size in a certain brand, it’s even easier. You don’t need to overthink it. Plus, some people wear the same kind of thing every day, like jeans and a plain shirt, and when something gets worn out, they just order the same one again. For that kind of shopping, online is perfect.

Why do some people like to make others laugh?
I think a lot of people like making others laugh because it just feels good… for both sides. When you make someone laugh, especially someone who might be having a rough day, there’s this instant connection. It’s like, for a moment, things feel lighter. And you can see it happen… their face changes, they relax, they smile. That’s a really nice feeling, and I think some people get kind of hooked on that. Not in a bad way, but just… it makes them feel good too. Also, for some people, humor is how they navigate the world. Like, they’ve always been the funny one in the group or the person who tells stories in a way that cracks everyone up. It becomes part of their identity, you know? And I think it can also be a kind of armor. When things get awkward or tense, they joke. When they feel nervous, they joke. It’s how they handle stuff, and if it makes others laugh in the process, that’s a bonus. So it’s about connection, comfort, and even coping. Making someone laugh is a way of reaching out and saying, ‘Hey, life’s not so bad right now.’

What kind of people like comedy?
I’d say people who like comedy are usually pretty easygoing. They don’t take life too seriously and enjoy finding the funny side of everyday situations. You also see it a lot in social people, the ones who love being around others, joking, laughing, sharing funny stories. Comedy just fits their personality. What's the difference between the Internet and television?
Well, the Internet and television are two different forms of media that have distinct characteristics and serve different purposes. The Internet is a digital network that is accessed via computers, smartphones, or other devices, and offers a vast array of content, including text, images, videos, and audio, as well as interactive features such as forums, blogs, and social media. The Internet is highly interactive, allowing users to engage with content, communicate with others, and share information, and is available 24 by 7 and can be accessed from almost anywhere with an internet connection. On the other hand, television is a traditional broadcast medium that is received via a television set. It primarily offers linear programming such as news, sports, and entertainment, and is generally a one-way form of communication with limited options for user interaction. Television is available for limited hours of operation and is only available in certain geographic locations, and the cost of accessing television is typically included as part of a cable or satellite subscription. To sum up, the Internet offers more interactivity, content options, accessibility, and cost flexibility compared to television.

Honestly, not every novel is a good fit for a movie, but there are definitely some that just feel right for the screen. If the story has a clear beginning, middle, and end, and doesn’t go off into a million directions, it’s much easier to turn into a solid movie. You don’t want to spend half the film trying to explain random side plots. And of course, character-driven stories work really well too. If a novel has strong, relatable characters with real goals and struggles, it just pulls people in even if the plot itself is simple. It’s those emotional moments, the growth, the relationships… that’s what sticks. I’d also say anything with suspense or high stakes usually makes a good movie. Like a thriller or a mystery where you just have to know what happens next. It keeps the energy up and the audience hooked.

How do children socialize with each other?
To my mind, children socialize with each other in a variety of ways, depending on their age, personality, and social context. One of the most common ways children socialize is through playing together, whether it's at home, school, or in a park. During play, children engage in imaginative play, such as pretending to be superheroes, or games that involve physical activity, like tag or hide-and-seek. These activities help children develop social skills such as taking turns, sharing, and cooperating. Another way children socialize is through talking to each other. They may engage in conversations about topics that interest them, such as their favorite books, movies, or video games, or share stories about their experiences. By conversing with their peers, children develop their communication and listening skills. Additionally, children may collaborate on projects or share activities like drawing, painting, or playing music together. These activities teach children to work together, appreciate each other's creativity, and develop their social skills. Participating in sports or other extracurricular activities is also a way for children to socialize. These activities can help them build friendships, learn to work together towards a common goal, and develop their teamwork and leadership skills. Finally, attending parties or social events is another way for children to socialize with their peers in a fun and relaxed environment. Social events like birthday parties or play dates allow children to interact with each other, make conversation, introduce themselves, and make new friends. In conclusion, there are many ways for children to socialize with each other, and each interaction provides an opportunity for them to develop important social skills that will serve them well throughout their lives.

How do children socialize with each other?
I think the easiest way children connect is by playing games together. It doesn’t matter if they know each other well or not. Once someone says ‘Wanna play?’ things just start to flow. Why do some people quit and change jobs?
To my mind, there are several reasons why people decide to quit their jobs and look for new opportunities. One common reason is the desire for career advancement. Many individuals seek jobs that offer better prospects for moving up the ladder and achieving their long-term goals. Another significant factor is the pursuit of a higher salary. People often consider changing jobs if they believe they can earn more elsewhere, which can provide financial stability and a better quality of life. Work-life balance also plays a crucial role. Nowadays, people value their personal time and want a job that allows them to strike a healthier balance between work and life commitments. A flexible schedule or reduced working hours can be enticing. Company culture is another key aspect. Toxic or unsupportive work environments can be mentally and emotionally draining, which prompts individuals to explore workplaces with a more positive atmosphere and a culture that aligns with their values. Furthermore, the lack of recognition or appreciation at their current job can lead to dissatisfaction. Many seek new opportunities where their contributions are acknowledged and valued. Personal factors like geographic relocation, health issues, and changes in life circumstances can also influence the decision to change jobs. So, it’s a mix of professional and personal considerations that drive people to take that step.

What are the reasons for job change?
One big reason is definitely the desire for career advancement. Like, if someone’s been in the same role for years with no chance to grow, it gets frustrating. People want to feel like they’re moving forward, not just doing the same thing on repeat. Another huge reason is the lack of recognition or appreciation at their current job. You know, when you work hard every day and no one even says thank you, it starts to wear you down. After a while, it’s not just about money… it’s about feeling valued. So when people see an opportunity to be taken seriously somewhere else, they often go for it. I think it’s pretty understandable.

Can you trust other people’s travel journals on the Internet?
It really depends on what the person is describing. If they're talking about something objective, like the height of a monument or the history of a landmark, then we can trust it more, as long as they provide reliable sources or include photos for comparison. For example, if someone says a statue is 5 meters tall and was built in a certain year by a specific person, and they back that up with sources or images, we can generally trust it. But when it comes to personal feelings and subjective impressions, it gets tricky. Our brains tend to distort information based on our own experiences, past traumas, or beliefs. For instance, what one person finds ‘big’ might seem small to someone else, or what one person thinks is beautiful might not be to someone else. Even simple things like what’s considered ‘expensive’ or ‘cheap’ can vary. So, when someone’s describing their personal perception of a place or experience, it’s harder to trust fully, because it's filtered through their individual lens.

Which is more dangerous, team sports or individual sports?
I’d say both team sports and individual sports can be dangerous, but the risks come from different places. In team sports, the danger usually comes from all the physical contact. You’re always bumping into people, tackling, and running into them, which increases the chance of getting hurt. Sports like football, rugby, and hockey are high-contact, and you might end up with sprains, fractures, or even head injuries, like concussions. There’s a lot of physical strain on your joints, too. In football, for example, the constant running and sudden stops put a lot of pressure on your knees and ankles. In individual sports, the risk of injury can be especially high because of the environment. In sports like rock climbing or skiing, even a small mistake can lead to serious injury or worse. It’s not just about making a mistake. It’s the environment that makes it so much more dangerous. For example, tripping on flat ground is one thing, but losing your balance while climbing a rock face or skiing down a slope can have much more severe consequences. The environment itself (steep cliffs, icy slopes, or unpredictable weather) turns any wrong move into a much higher risk. In skiing, you can easily lose control and crash, or in rock climbing, one wrong move can lead to a serious fall. Solo sports also put a lot of pressure on you to keep pushing yourself. For example, in running or swimming, overdoing it without proper recovery can lead to overuse injuries, like tendonitis or stress fractures.

How does advertising affect people?
There are a lot of ways advertising affects people, both positively and negatively, but I’ll highlight the main points. On the positive side, advertising helps people find solutions to their problems. For example, if someone is struggling with back pain and doesn’t know about a product that could help, an ad might show them exactly what they need. It’s a quick way to get the solution without wasting time searching. Advertising also saves time. Sometimes, we’d spend ages looking for a product, but then an ad pops up and suddenly we don’t have to waste any more time, it shows us exactly what we’ve been looking for. Another positive is that advertising informs people about new opportunities. Ads often introduce products or services that people might not know exist, helping them find better solutions for what they need. For example, a new app or service could improve someone’s life in a way they didn’t even think of before. Plus, ads help people make quick decisions, like when you see a limited-time offer and make a purchase quickly, saving time and effort. On the flip side, it often encourages impulse buying, especially with things like ‘limited time only’ offers. A good example is Temu, where you’re bombarded with discounts and free gifts, and before you know it, you’ve added a bunch of items to your cart, even though you didn’t need anything at first. Ads also manipulate emotions. For instance, ads for beauty products or weight loss solutions make people feel insecure, pushing them to buy things to fix perceived flaws. Finally, advertising leads to overspending. Ads can tempt people to buy more than they can afford. Whether it's through ‘limited time’ offers or showing how everyone else has a product, people often feel pressured to spend money they don’t have, sometimes even going into debt.

Well, it really depends. On one hand, seeing the same ad everywhere can get kind of annoying. If you're constantly bombarded with the same thing, whether it's on your phone, in the subway, or on TV, it can feel overwhelming. After a while, you might start tuning it out, especially if it’s something you're not interested in. However, repetition can actually be a good thing for brand recognition. If you see an ad for a product just once, it’s easy to forget. With the constant flood of information we’re exposed to every day, it's hard to remember everything that catches our attention. But when you see the same ad multiple times, it starts to stick in your mind. You might not immediately buy the product, but over time, you’ll remember it when you actually need it. For example, you might see an ad for a new phone or a gym membership several times, and after a while, when you're actually looking for a new phone or thinking about getting fit, that ad will pop into your mind.

Why do stories and movies for children always feature animals?
There are a few reasons why animals are such a big part of stories and movies for kids. First, animals are relatable for children, even though they’re not humans. Kids can connect with animals because they often have simple, clear characteristics that are easy for children to understand. For example, a lion might be brave, or a rabbit might be timid. These traits are easy to recognize, making it easier for kids to connect emotionally with the characters. Animals also help teach important lessons. In many children’s stories, animals are used to show values like friendship, loyalty, and courage. Kids can learn a lot from these stories – how to be brave like a lion, or kind like a dog. These lessons are often taught through the behavior of animals, which makes them easier for kids to grasp. Another reason animals are so common in children’s media is because they can make the stories more fun and imaginative. Animals allow for more creativity, like talking animals or animals with magical abilities, which can make the story exciting and full of adventure. Plus, kids find animals entertaining. Kids are curious about them, and seeing animals in movies or stories makes the whole experience more engaging. Lastly, animals in stories are often used to represent different emotions or ideas. For instance, in fables or fairy tales, an animal’s behavior can symbolize something more complex, like a wolf being seen as dangerous or a dove representing peace. This helps children understand abstract ideas in a simple, easy-to-understand way.

Do you think some children are well-behaved JUST because they are influenced by their parents?
Yeah, it is certainly possible. First of all, kids are like sponges. They absorb everything around them. I mean they learn by watching and trying to imitate what people around them do. So if children spend almost all their time with their parents, it's perfectly natural that they copy what their parents are doing. And if parents model good behavior themselves and lead by example, kids are more likely to emulate that behavior. Plus, parents are the biggest influence on a child's behavior 'cause they are typically the primary caregivers for their children. So it is parents that set the rules and set an example for their kids to follow. And if a kid has parents who are strict and set high expectations for their behavior, the kid is more likely to be well-behaved. For example, if a parent is constantly reminding their kid to say 'please' and 'thank you', and teaching them how to be respectful to others, chances are that kid is going to pick up on those good habits and behave well. What's more, it is parents that have authority to provide consistent consequences for misbehavior such as taking away privileges or imposing extra chores for not following rules. So sometimes it really boils down to how much effort and attention the parents put into raising their kids. If they make a conscious effort to teach their kids good manners and how to behave, I think it's likely that the kids will turn out well-behaved just because of their parents' influence. However, there are many other factors that can affect a child's behavior as well, such as their environment, peers, and individual personality and temperament. I mean, the reasons for a child's behavior can be complex and varied, and it's not always possible to attribute it to one specific factor.

What problems will occur if people don’t recycle?
There are a few big issues that could happen if people stop recycling. First of all, more trash will END UP in landfills, which is a huge problem. Landfills will FILL UP faster, and that means we’ll need even more space to store all the waste, which isn’t sustainable. Plus, when things decompose in landfills, they release harmful gases, like methane, that contribute to climate change. Another issue is that a lot of materials, like plastic and metal, could just END UP sitting in the environment forever. It takes hundreds of years for plastic to BREAK DOWN, so if we don’t recycle it, it could pollute oceans, rivers, and landscapes, harming wildlife in the process. Not recycling also means we’re wasting valuable resources. Materials like paper, metal, and glass can be reused, but if we throw them away instead, we need to DIG UP more raw materials, which takes energy and contributes to deforestation and pollution. In the long run, that could lead to resource shortages. So, in short, if we don’t recycle, we’ll have more waste, more pollution, and we’ll USE UP resources faster than we can replenish them.

Do you think parents should teach children how to cooperate with others?
Definitely. I think it’s super important for parents to teach their kids how to cooperate with others. Cooperation is one of those life skills that you can’t really do without, whether it’s in school, at work, or just in everyday life. And honestly, kids don’t just pick it up on their own. They need to be taught how to share, take turns, compromise, and work as a team. Parents are the first ones who can show them these skills. Like, when a parent teaches their child to share their toys with others or helps them navigate a disagreement with a friend, they’re laying the foundation for cooperation. It’s not just about telling kids, ‘You need to share,’ but about showing them why it matters and how it makes everyone feel better. Also, when kids see their parents cooperating with others, they learn by example. If a parent is working together with others, whether it’s in the family or with people outside the family, the child picks up on those behaviors. So, it’s not just about giving instructions; it’s about modeling cooperation, too. I also think teaching cooperation helps kids develop empathy. They learn to understand others’ feelings and realize that it’s not all about them. And that’s such an important lesson for their social development. So yeah, I really believe parents should teach their kids how to cooperate with others.

How do people have a conversation with an elderly person?
There are a few things to keep in mind when talking to older people. Many people would say that respect is the most important thing, and I get that, but I actually think respect should be there for everyone, no matter their age. What really matters when talking to older people is being patient. Sometimes, they might need a bit more time to process information or respond. And, of course, hearing can be an issue for some, so it’s important to speak clearly and make sure they can hear you. Also, there’s something like a generation gap. Older people grew up in a completely different time, so their views on life can be quite different from ours. Their personalities were shaped by experiences from many years ago, and that’s why they might not always understand our way of thinking, and we may not always understand theirs. It’s important not to criticize their views or get frustrated when they offer advice that seems outdated. Instead, we should be tolerant and respond calmly. Another thing is, older people often feel lonely, so it’s really nice to ask them about their life and experiences. Giving them a chance to talk about their past makes them feel heard and appreciated.

First of all, I’m sure there will be more tall buildings in the future, and they will be even taller than the ones we have today. Secondly, in the future, buildings might use materials that don’t harm the environment. What would people normally consider when they rent or buy a house or an apartment?
When people rent or buy a house or an apartment, they usually think about a few important things. First, they consider the location. They want to know if it’s close to their work, school, or places they visit often. Second, they look at the price to make sure it’s something they can afford. The size of the place is also important. Some people need more space, while others prefer smaller places. They also think about the number of rooms, like bedrooms and bathrooms, to see if it fits their needs. The condition of the house or apartment matters too. People want to know if it’s clean and in good shape or if it needs repairs. Safety is another factor, as people want to live in a safe area. Lastly, the neighborhood and any extra facilities, like parking or a garden, can make a big difference. For example, if there is a person with disabilities, they might need a place with ramps, wider doors, or other special features.

In some cities, torrential beating of heavy rains competes with calls to prayer and howls of stray dogs. The part that feels the most crazy in most big cities is downtown: drivers honk constantly, lots of people speak simultaneously, engines roar. From early morning until midnight, streets in most cities are full of motorbikes and street vendors. There are always a bunch of kids shouting or people playing musical instruments. Oh, and there are a lot of billboards with ad videos that have sounds. Also, in some cities, a lot of noise comes from places of worship. Sometimes biker gangs roar through the city. So, yes, nowadays city life is nothing more than an awful din of traffic, construction and other raucous sounds.
